user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_probe_bus:
```c
static int metal_linux_probe_bus(struct linux_bus *lbus)
{
	struct linux_driver *ldrv;
	int ret, error = -ENODEV;

	lbus->sbus = sysfs_open_bus(lbus->bus_name);
	if (!lbus->sbus)
		return -ENODEV;

	for_each_linux_driver(lbus, ldrv) {
		ret = metal_linux_probe_driver(lbus, ldrv);
		/* Clear the error if any driver is available */
		if (!ret)
			error = ret;
	}

	if (error) {
		metal_linux_bus_close(&lbus->bus);
		return error;
	}

	error = metal_linux_register_bus(lbus);
	if (error)
		metal_linux_bus_close(&lbus->bus);

	return error;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No suspicious fragments found with respect to MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8. Specifically:
- The only write to the object referred to by the pointer parameter is lbus->sbus = sysfs_open_bus(lbus->bus_name); modifying a member of the object pointed to by lbus is allowed by the rule (the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified).
- There is no assignment to the parameter identifier lbus itself (no statements like lbus = ...), so the pointer parameter is not modified.
- Passing lbus (or &lbus->bus) to other functions (metal_linux_probe_driver, metal_linux_bus_close, metal_linux_register_bus) is not a modification of the parameter within this function; such calls may modify the pointed object but that is permitted.
- The for_each_linux_driver(lbus, ldrv) usage and reads of lbus->bus_name are read operations and do not reassign the parameter.
Therefore no code fragments in this function violate Rule 17.8 and no further investigation is required for this rule.
